Summary The core of my scholarship experience revolves around the understanding of local knowledge, perceptions and responses to crises in the 21st Century. The Ph.D. dissertation demonstrates that the study of cognitive and symbolic aspects of weather and climate is as important as the study of responses to specific weather events or conditions. What people know about weather and climate conditions (the categorical knowledge that help them describe weather and climate) and what people feel (the knowledge based on senses and moral order that help people comprehend weather and climate) both evoke strong responses. Moreover, values and beliefs about spirituality, nature, morality, work, sociality, and responsibility, linked to experience-based ecological and economic knowledge, appear to be the main ingredients in people's responses to any type of crises. Knowledge, perceptions and responses to crises then, are inseparable domains; and the understanding of one should include the analysis of the others. Experience Clinical Research Coordinator Stanford University School of Medicine April 2015  – Present (5 months) Stanford Center for Clinical Research (SCCR) In this position, as a member of the Stanford Center for Clinical Research (SCCR), I work across multiple therapeutic areas and/or Divisions and Principal Investigators, depending on the studies available at a given time. In general, I am responsible for the overall management and implementation of clinical research protocols.  Clinical Research Coordinator Stanford University School of Medicine September 2014  –  April 2015  (8 months) March of Dimes Prematurity Research Center As a Clinical Research Coordinator (CRC) I am responsible for the overall management and implementation of multiple clinical research protocols in assuring efficiency and regulatory compliance. I support clinical research studies with a focus on preterm birth, including epidemiological and investigative work in support of clinical research and biomedical research focusing on “bench to bedside” technology. The primary population I work with is pregnant women. Data Consultant Lucile Packard Foundation for Children's Health September 2012  –  August 2014  (2 years) San Francisco Bay Area My goal was to assist the kidsdata.org team in ensuring the quality, rigor and comprehensiveness of data provided on the website and through related data and information products. Research Assistant Stanford University June 2012  –  May 2013  (1 year) San Francisco Bay Area My primary responsibilities were to conduct necessary literature reviews, to coordinate stakeholder interviews (patients and providers), to assist with IRB protocol development and communications, and to assist with data management, data presentation, and preparation of manuscripts. I reported directly to Dr. Lee M. Sanders. Quality Assurance Analyst Telenav May 2012  –  June 2012  (2 months) Sunnyvale, CA As a quality assurance analyst at a software firm I tested navigational programs to make sure they were reliable, fully functional, and user-friendly. I inspected multiple lines of code to make sure they were entirely error-free. As analyst I also looked for weaknesses in the program, such as an unappealing interface or a slow loading speed. I explained my findings to technicians so the correct tweaks could be made. Once the program was completed, I reviewed it once again before it was released to the public. Ph.D. University of Kent September 2007  –  April 2012  (4 years 8 months) By extending ethnobiological and ethnographic methods to the study of climate variation, my investigation among Kenyah Badeng in the village of Data Kakus, Sarawak, East Malaysia, aimed to understand how traditional knowledge of weather and climate influences individual and collective decisions concerning agriculture and other economic activities. Bilingual Ads Quality Rater Google December 2006  –  July 2007  (8 months) The job involved analyzing and providing feedback on text, web pages, images and other types of information for Google, using online tools and Google guidelines on how to choose a rating for a result. The position required in-depth, current knowledge of web culture and media, the ability to deal with a broad range of interests and topics, excellent communication skills and web analytic capabilities. Data Collector Stanford University November 2006  –  July 2007  (9 months) Stanford, California In 2006, I joined a multi-disciplinary team for a two-year community based evaluation of after school team sports compared with health education for weight control in overweight children. This job required the ability to follow research protocols, excellent communication and interpersonal skills, and flexibility to work non/standard hours including early mornings, evenings and weekends. Laboratory Technician USDA August 2005  –  June 2006  (11 months) Reno, Nevada Area As Laboratory Technician, I was responsible for data collection in the field and the laboratory. This work involved setting up, collecting, and gathering physiological data from remote field sites. I processed samples from the field and prepared them for chemical analysis. I was also responsible for entering and organizing data and its general maintenance. Then, I developed strong decision-making skills and the ability to work with accuracy in a fast paced work environment. Research Assistant University of Nevada Reno August 2003  –  June 2005  (1 year 11 months) Reno, Nevada Area During my Master's degree at the University of Nevada, Reno, I worked for two years in the Basque Library Studies. This work concerned the search for, translation, scanning, and indexing of articles and documents related to Basque topics. The goal was to place on the Internet 300,000 summaries and/or full texts. Then, I acquired experience in library databases, international catalogues, and administrative support. One of my responsibilities was to establish and maintain communication with scholars, students, and librarians from many different countries. I also developed administrative experience in resource management and bookkeeping through the incorporation of new materials in the collection and control of the main catalogue.
